article.headline: European stocks turn higher as improving economic data offset downbeat bank results
article.body: Commuters wearing face masks travel on a tram past HSBC signage outside the bank's local headquarters in Hong Kong on April 28, 2020. anthony wallace/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images European stocks turned higher on Monday after early losses, as improving data on the economy helped offset disappointing results from HSBC Holdings and Société Générale. Up 1.1% in July, the Stoxx Europe 600 SXXP, +0.55% rose 0.5%. The German DAX DAX, +0.06% rose 1.2% and the French CAC 40 PX1, +0.71% added 0.4% as the U.K. FTSE 100 UKX, +0.64% slipped. U.S. stock futures ES00, +1.13% eased after a 5.5% gain for the S&P 500 SPX, +0.87% in July. Lawmakers reported progress on a new stimulus package over the weekend but gaps remained between Democrats and Republicans. The Caixin China manufacturing purchasing managers index rose to 52.8 in July, with the best readings for output and new orders since January 2011. Spain’s manufacturing PMI rose to 53.5, its best showing since April 2018, as the final manufacturing PMI reading for the eurozone came in stronger than the flash report. The U.S. economics calendar includes the Institute for Supply Management’s manufacturing index and a number of nonvoting Federal Reserve officials speaking. Of companies in the spotlight, HSBC Holdings HSBA, -1.49% HSBC, -0.93% dropped after reporting a 77% drop in first-half net profit. Société Générale GLE, -1.41% declined after reporting a € 1.26 billion loss for the second quarter. Siemens Heathineers SHL, +1.62% slipped 5% after reaching a deal to buy radiation therapy software company Varian Medical Systemsms VAR, +0.04% for $16.4 billion. Siemens SIE, +0.65% said its stake in Siemens Heathineers will fall to 72% from 85% as part of the fundraising for the deal. Morphosys MOR, +2.89% MOR, +2.90% jumped after the biotech company got accelerated approval from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for a lymphoma drug.
